subject: Education
title: Pygmalion Effect: Expectations Shape Reality
description: A fast breakdown of Pygmalion Effect: Expectations Shape Reality for builders.

hook.text: Teachers were told random students were 'late bloomers.' Those students' IQs actually rose.

buildup.text: Rosenthal and Jacobson's 1968 experiment showed that teacher expectations alter student outcomes.

discovery.text: High expectations lead to warmer tone, more feedback, harder material, and more wait time for answers.

twist.text: The effect works in reverse too: low expectations produce lower achievement (the Golem effect).

climax.text: Expectations are communicated through thousands of micro-behaviors teachers aren't even aware of.

punchline.text: Expect more and you get more. It's not magicâ€”it's behavior.
